MainHeading.P: Do chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 3 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Appointment of Ministers.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether he will state when the appointment of Ministers and the allocation of Departments referred to by him in Dáil Éireann on 13th June, 1951, as not being finally fixed will, in fact, be finally announced.

As I told the Dáil on the 13th June it is probable that, at a later stage, it will be necessary to have separate Ministers for Health and Social Welfare. Subject to this, the assignment of Departments may now be regarded as fixed.

Does the Taoiseach not consider it desirable that there should be separate Ministers in charge of Social Welfare and of Health as soon as possible because of the many varied problems that have to be dealt with by these two Departments?

I think I indicated that that was my view, but I also pointed out that it was desirable for the present that the Minister who had been in charge of these Departments originally should be allowed to continue until the road is somewhat clearer.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kildare Health Inspector.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he is aware that on 3rd February, 1951, the Kildare County Council sent the statutory request to the Local Appointments Commission for the selection by the commission of a health inspector, and if he will state whether the appropriate advertisements for applications have been issued; and, if so, on what date.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach (Donnchadh Ó Briain) Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach (Donnchadh Ó Briain)
Speaker.P: The statutory request referred to by the Deputy was received by the Local Appointments Commissioners on the 6th February, 1951; the vacancy has not yet been advertised, but the commissioners hope to be in a position to advertise it shortly.

The delay in advertising this vacancy has been due mainly to the fact that, at the time when the statutory request was received by the commissioners, the Minister concerned had under consideration the making of a revised declaration of qualifications for this type of post generally, so as to give a concession, as regards the maximum age-limit for candidates, to certain temporary officers of local authorities. In addition to this, the commissioners propose, in accordance with their normal practice, to hold a single combined competition for the post mentioned in the question and a number of similar posts under other local authorities in which vacancies also happen to exist; the making of the necessary administrative arrangements for this purpose has further contributed to the delay.
Can the Parliamentary Secretary say when the matter will be dealt with?

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: As soon as possible.
I have heard that one before.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Butter Production.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will state the total number of gallons of milk delivered to creameries during the period 1st January to 31st May, 1951, and the number of cwt. of butter manufactured in the same period with comparative figures for 1950.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The approximate total quantity of milk delivered to creameries in the 21-weeks period ended on the 28th May, 1951, was 42,002,000 gallons. The total quantity of creamery butter manufactured during the period 1st January to 31st May, 1951, was 127,892 cwt. The corresponding figures for the same periods in 1950 were 54,403,000 gallons and 180,386 cwt. respectively. Particulars of the production of farmers' butter are not available for the periods referred to.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Deliveries of Pigs to Factories.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will state the total number of bacon pigs delivered to bacon factories during the period 1st January to 31st May, 1951, with comparative figures for 1950.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The total number of pigs received at bacon factories for curing during the period 1st January to 31st May, 1951, was 196,301. The corresponding figure for the same period of 1850 was 285,801.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Slaughter of Calves.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will state the total number of calves slaughtered in the period 1st January, 1951, to 31st May, 1951, and in the same period of 1950.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The total number of calves slaughtered in the period 1st January to 31st March, 1951, the latest date up to which the information is available, was 2,600. The number slaughtered in the same period of 1950 was 2,900.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Coal Supplies.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state what allocation of coal will be available to Ireland for the second half of this year and if any further supplies are being made available from the United States of America or elsewhere.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lemass) Seán F. Lemass
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lemass)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is no doubt aware, coal supplies are allocated amongst European countries, including Ireland, on a quarterly basis by the Coal Committees of O.E.E.C. at Paris and the Economic Commission for Europe at Geneva. Allocations for the third quarter of this year have not yet been fixed. Arrangements have been made to import coal from the United States of America to whatever extent may be required, subject to shipping being available for its transportation, during the balance of the year.
Would the Minister say whether the British Government has yet indicated what allocation it will make available to this country in the third and fourth quarters of this year?
No, not finally.
Have any provisional figures been received from the British Government?
Yes, but I think the position will have to be clarified somewhat.
Can the Minister say whether the figure will be at least as good as it was in the last quarter?
I should hope so.
Would the Minister say when he hopes to be in a position to make a definite statement on the matter?
In about a fortnight's time.
Are these figures subject to confirmation by O.E.E.C.?
Certainly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Price of Meat.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that there has been a continuous rise in the price of meat; and, if so, if he will state what proposals, if any, are being made to retain for home consumption sufficient meat at a reasonable price to the consumers, without causing loss to those in the retail meat-selling trade who state that they can no longer continue in the business unless the Government buy in the markets and distribute to the victuallers supplies at a wholesale price that will enable them to sell meat to the consumers at a fair price without loss to themselves; and, further, if he will state if it is proposed to subsidise the meat traders or the tanneries, or both.

I am aware that, between mid-February and mid-May of this year, there were increases in the prices of fresh beef and mutton. The question of the prices of fresh beef and mutton and the other matters referred to by the Deputy are under examination.

asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware (a) that his Department was informed in April of this year of the fact that prices were being charged markedly in excess of those fixed by the State for the retail sale of beef and requested to indicate what remedy was open to the housewife when overcharged, and (b) that the Department's reply seemed to indicate that an intended change of law excused open breach of that law; and, if so, if he will state what steps he intends to take to deal with open defiance of the law in this matter and for the protection of the housewife against overcharging.

I am aware that a complaint of the nature referred to by the Deputy in the first part of his question was received by the Department in April and that a reply was issued to the effect that the question of the revision of fresh meat prices was under consideration and that it had not yet been possible to reach a decision in the matter.
I am having the whole position regarding fresh meat prices examined.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dungarvan Leather Factory.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he is aware that 50 workers employed at a leather factory in Dungarvan are under one week's notice and that the balance of the workers are warned that they will be required to go on short time; and, if so, if he will state whether it is correct that the home trade will be unable to take any supplies until August of finished light leather and if he will, in the circumstances, grant a licence for the export of this type of leather and thus prevent the 50 men from losing their employment and the balance of over 100 men from being put on short time.

I was informed by the Deputy that the position was as stated in the first part of the question but as an export licence sought by the company had, prior to the receipt of the Deputy's communication, already issued, I assume that the position to which he refers no longer obtains. I have decided that export licences will continue to be granted for any leather produced by the company which is surplus to, or unsuited for, the requirements of the home footwear manufacturers, and the company has been so informed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Proposed Cork Air Service.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether his Department is prepared to co-operate with the Cork airways company by providing the necessary facilities at Cork airport to enable a scheduled air service to be operated from Cork.
The provision of regular air services from Cork is a matter to which I propose to give consideration but it is likely to be some time before a final decision can be reached.

The present position is that an airfield has been provided and is being operated at Farmer's Cross, Cork, by private interests, and a licence has been issued authorising the use of that airfield by aircraft plying for hire subject to certain conditions. The airfield is being used for private and charter flights.

Before the operation of regular services from this airport could be authorised it would be necessary, in the interests of safety, to set up a meteorological organisation there. This is not at present practicable because of a shortage of forecasting staff, some difficulty having already been experienced in obtaining sufficient trained personnel for Dublin and Shannon airports. This is one of the factors which will have to be taken into account when the general question is under consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Supplies of Drapery Goods.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state if his Department has received repeated complaints from wholesale drapery firms concerning the failure of certain manufacturing firms to supply blankets, towels and other household requirements or to complete orders within a reasonable time from the date of acceptance; whether some of the firms concerned were granted export licences to sell these essential commodities in foreign markets above the prices fixed for the home market, and if he will state what action has been or will be taken in this matter.

Complaints were received from certain wholesale drapery firms in autumn of last year as to a shortage of blankets, towels and other household requirements. These articles were not then, and are not at present, subject to export control. Temporary arrangements were made last year for the importation of these articles, free of duty or of quota restrictions, in sufficient quantities to meet requirements.
No complaints of the kind referred to have been received for some time past. Irish manufacturers appear to be meeting all reasonable demands, and I do not propose to take any action in the matter.

Will the Minister, when he has time, look up the files of his Department this year and having done so, will he then come and say he has received no complaints in regard to the shortage of towels? Will he also say whether there is an obligation on a manufacturing firm, getting tariffs at the expense of the community, to provide for the reasonable requirements of the home market before looking for an export licence?

As I have explained, an export licence is not required for these articles. I should certainly think it would be good business for a firm operating here to supply the requirements of its permanent customers before sending goods out of the country.
Will the Minister make inquiries to ascertain whether Gentex, Athlone, are supplying the reasonable requirements of their home customers?
Knowing how efficient that firm is, I am quite certain they are doing that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Store Street Bus Station.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state the total cost incurred by Córas Iompair Éireann for the proposed bus station at Store Street, the amount received for the sale of the station to the Department of Social Welfare, whether he has ordered the board of Córas Iompair Éireann to buy this building again; and, if so, at what price and how he proposes to provide the money for this purpose.

I am informed by Córas Iompair Éireann that the total cost incurred on the Store Street premises up to the date of its sale to the Department of Social Welfare was £388,104. The full amount will be paid to the board by the Department of Social Welfare. It has been decided that the central bus station will be located in this building and this decision has been communicated to Córas Iompair Éireann. It is intended that the company should lease from the Department of Social Welfare such portions of the building as will be required for the operation of the bus station. The rent, which will be paid from the funds generally at the disposal of the company, has not yet been determined.

Will the Minister say whether the decision to put this bus station, this white elephant, back at Store Street is a Government decision? Will he also say whether it was done for the purpose of pacifying Deputy Peadar Cowan and satisfying the traders in the area?
It was done primarily for the purpose of satisfying the people of the country who had been waiting for many years for a bus station.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Herbertstown (Kildare) Canal Bridge.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that the Kildare County Council are anxious that the Herbertstown branch of the canal should be closed for traffic purposes so that the council may erect a new bridge on a less steep incline instead of the present dangerous bridge on this, the main road to the whole South of Ireland; and, if so, what action he proposes to take in the matter.

I am aware that a proposal has been made by the Kildare County Council for the construction of a new bridge over the Herbertstown branch of the Grand Canal to replace the existing bridge. The construction of the bridge would close the canal to navigation. Córas Iompair Éireann, before agreeing to the proposal, would require an order from the Transport Tribunal releasing it from its obligation to keep the canal open for navigation.

I am informed by Córas Iompair Éireann that before applying for the necessary order, certain outstanding points require to be settled with the county council. The county council were invited in March, 1951, to suggest a suitable date for discussion but have rot yet done so.
Will the Minister bear in mind the inadvisability of closing any portion of the canal without giving the matter very careful consideration?
Certainly. The Minister will not be called upon to make a decision until he has received a report from the Transport Tribunal.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ballina Harbour Improvements.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state whether he has received particulars of the necessary repairs and improvements to Ballina Harbour from the Moy Harbour Commissioners, Ballina, County Mayo; and, if so, when it is proposed to make the necessary moneys available.

I have received particulars of the repairs and improvements which the River Moy Harbour Commissioners consider necessary at Ballina Harbour. The application for a State grant to meet the cost of repairs and improvements at the harbour is under consideration, and I expect to be in a position to communicate a decision to the commissioners in the near future.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - New Ross Harbour.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if the survey and preparation of an estimate for the improvement of facilities at New Ross Harbour have yet been completed; and, if so, what is the result.
The survey at New Ross Harbour in connection with the proposal to construct a jetty there has been completed, but the preparation of plans and estimates will take a considerable time.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kildare Valuations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state whether, in respect of newly-erected houses in County Kildare, valuations are determined by the number of rooms and the floor area; and, if so, the basis of such determination.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Beegan) Patrick Beegan
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Beegan)
Speaker.P: In accordance with Section 11 of the Valuation (Ireland) Act, 1852, the valuation of newly-erected houses in County Kildare as elsewhere is based on their net annual value. In arriving at his estimate of the net annual value of a house the revising valuer is influenced by the number of rooms and the floor area, but he also takes into account the user of the premises, i.e., whether it is occupied merely as a residence or in conjunction with a farm, its situation, the materials used in its construction, the services laid on, the internal and external finish and everything which he thinks would influence the net annual value.
Can the Parliamentary Secretary get the Valuation Office to give a simple definition of the basis on which they arrive at these valuations?
As I pointed out to the Deputy, it is in accordance with Section 11 of the Valuation Act, 1852. Provision is made for the many factors that arise.
That was over 100 years ago.

asked the Minister for Finance if he will state in respect of the 100 houses listed for the first time in the valuation lists for the current financial year for County Kildare, the number of such houses that had three rooms, four rooms and five or more rooms respectively, differentiating in each case between those with and those without water and sewerage, and, further, if he will state the total valuations of each such class of house.
The information asked for by the Deputy is contained in a tabular statement which, with the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, will be incorporated in the Official Report.
Following is the statement:—
NEWLY-ERECTED DWELLINGS INCLUDED FOR THE FIRST TIME IN THE VALUATION LISTS OPERATIVE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1951/52 IN COUNTY KILDARE, EXCLUSIVE OF THE URBAN DISTRICTS OF NAAS AND ATHY.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garden of Remembrance.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if it is proposed to proceed with work on the Garden of Remembrance in the Rotunda Gardens; and, if so, when it is expected that the work will be completed.

The answer to the first part of the Deputy's question is in the affirmative. As regards the second part of his question, the Deputy will be aware from replies given by my predecessor to questions on this subject that the site was made available to the Rotunda Hospital authorities by the late Government as a temporary measure for the purposes of an infant welfare unit. Work on the Garden of Remembrance cannot be commenced until the temporary use of the site shall have ceased. Accordingly, it is not possible at this stage to say when the project will be completed, but meanwhile steps are being taken to have all work preparatory to the placing of contracts for the carrying out of the approved scheme put in hands, so that there may be no delay in proceeding with the work when the site becomes available. The Minister for Health is also being approached to expedite the provision of permanent accommodation for the infant welfare unit which at present occupies the site temporarily.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Moy Drainage Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state (a) where the River Moy drainage scheme is placed on the priority list; (b) when the survey is likely to commence; (c) whether it is intended to include Lough Cullen and Lough Conn on the general scheme; (d) pending the main arterial drainage scheme, if it is intended to give a temporary relief by the removal of three obstructions at Mountfalcon, Foxford and Cloonfee, and (e) whether he is aware that if those obstructions are not removed this summer a large number of small farmers adjoining the two lakes and the River Moy will be rendered penniless after another year similar to last winter through flooding.

As stated by me on the 28th June, 1951, in reply to a similar question by Deputy Ruttledge, this matter is at present under consideration. The Deputy might please repeat his question in about three weeks' time. I may say, however, that any comprehensive arterial drainage scheme for the River Moy will include Loughs Cullen and Conn.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bog Development Grant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance whether he will make available a bog development grant for the construction of a road and the sinking of a drain at Ballylin bog, Ferbane, County Offaly.

The proposal to which the Deputy refers is, presumably, the making of a link to connect two existing roads in Ballylin bog. As these existing roads serve all the banks which are being cut this season, and as they are at present in a fair state of repair, I do not see any necessity to make a grant to complete the link road.

The drain referred to in the question has as its outfall a drain maintainable by the Offaly County Council and could not be improved unless the latter was first deepened. My office will approach the county council in the matter.
Would the Parliamentary Secretary say who advised him or his Department that the road is in a fair state of repair?
I am sure that I am being advised by the same people who advised my predecessor in these matters.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ballyhack Harbour Company, Wexford.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will make a grant available for the dredging of the harbour at Ballyhack, County Wexford, as owing to the silting up of the harbour at high water the fishing boats are in jeopardy due to the breakwater being awash.
No application for a grant towards the cost of dredging at Ballyhack Harbour has come before us. I understand that responsibility for the dredging rests with the Wexford County Council.
As I am not a member of the body referred to, would the Parliamentary Secretary consider making representations in that behalf as the harbour, I am informed, is dangerous to boats at present?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hospital Accommodation in Monaghan.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state what progress has been made regarding the reconstruction of the old sanatorium in Monaghan for use as a fever hospital, and also what is the position regarding proposals to provide hospital accommodation for Carrickmacross and Clones.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Ryan) James Ryan
Speaker.P: Preliminary examination of plans for the conversion of the old sanatorium, Monaghan, to a county fever hospital has been carried out in my Department, but further documents are needed before this examination can be completed. I understand that these documents will be forwarded by the local authority in the very near future.

When the old sanatorium at Monaghan becomes available for patients, it is proposed to transfer thereto patients from the Carrickmacross and Clones Fever Hospitals and to convert those institutions to district hospitals. Plans for the conversion of Carrickmacross Fever Hospital to a district hospital were received in my Department some time ago but their examination was deferred pending a clarification of the position which had arisen in regard to the compulsory acquisition of land for the hospital and certain other matters relating to the accommodation of fever patients in the county. These matters have been disposed of and the plans are at present under examination in my Department.
No proposals have yet been received in regard to Clones Fever Hospital.
May I ask if the delay is due to the failure of the local authority to send on the necessary plans, or is the delay due to the Department?
I am afraid there are delays on both sides.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Erection of Health Clinic.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state when it is proposed to commence the erection of a health clinic at Rosslare Harbour.

A compulsory purchase Order for the acquisition of a site for this health clinic was made by the local authority in October, 1950, and an Order confirming the compulsory purchase Order was requested. An objection to the Order was made on behalf of the occupier of the site in question making it necessary to hold a public inquiry. As a necessary preliminary to appointing an inspector to conduct this inquiry, the local authority were asked on 20th January last to forward certain documents in connection with the Order but these documents have not yet been received in my Department. When the question of acquisition of site has been disposed of, the local authority may undertake the erection of the clinic without further reference of documents to my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: Has the Minister made recent representations to the local authority to forward the information requested on the 20th January or will he be prepared to do that now?
The local authority was reminded since.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Infectious Diseases Maintenance Regulations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is aware that, on the 15th March, 1951, the Kildare County Council requested his Department to sanction under the Infectious Diseases (Maintenance) Regulations that the Army pension payable to a patient should not be taken into account; and, if so, if he will state whether sanction has yet been given in this case, and, if so, on what date.

The answer to the first part of the question is “yes”. The county council were informed on the 3rd instant that if the circumstances of this man's case are as stated by him then his Army pension need not be taken into account in calculating the maintenance allowance payable to him.
It has been suggested to the council that the adjusted allowance might' be paid as from the date of the patient's appeal to the council provided he was otherwise eligible as from that date.
Did the Minister say the 3rd instant, yesterday?
Yes.
It is wonderful what the effect of a question is.
It is a great instrument of human liberty.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Appointment of Home Assistance Officers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Flynn Mr. J. Flynn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare whether he is aware that the county manager of Kerry, before making appointments for such positions as home assistance officers, has applicants interviewed by a selection board in the first instance; and, if so, if he will state whether this procedure is required or necessary.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Ryan) James Ryan
Speaker.P: The Local Government (Officers) Regulations, 1943, made under Part II of the Local Government Act, 1941, lay down the procedure to be followed in connection with the appointment of assistance officers. These regulations provide that, in general, the selection shall be by means of a competitive examination (not necessarily written), and I am satisfied that this is the best method which can be adopted. Qualifications for the post of assistance officer are declared by me, but individual appointments are dealt with locally, and I have no functions in regard to such appointments.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Irish News Agency.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for External Affairs if it is intended to maintain the Irish News Agency in existence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Aiken) Frank Aiken
Speaker.P: In the last financial year the sum of £29,000 was spent on the news agency. Its earnings amounted to £1,150. The Estimates for this financial year provide for the expenditure of £25,000 on the service. It is too soon yet to come to any definite judgment on the matter, but I shall make every effort to see that this sum is expended with a view to making the agency a success from the national aspect and to increasing its earning capacity.
Then it is proposed to continue the agency?
Is it correct that the revenue of the agency shows a steady increase in recent months?
I could not say exactly.
Do we understand the Minister to say that he intends to carry on the news agency?

We approach these matters a little bit differently from the late Government. We do not set out to stop all useful agencies of government as the Deputy suspended the land improvement and farm buildings schemes.

Do we understand the Minister to say that he intends to carry on the news agency? That question permits of a yes or no answer. If he still continues to wriggle, we will ask the question again in a fortnight.
The Deputy can ask any question he likes. I said that I shall make every effort——
Yes or no.
I said that I would make every effort to see that this agency for which the Dáil has provided £25,000 is a success from the national point of view and the financial point of view.
May I inquire if this is, in fact, a reversal of the view expressed by the present Minister for Industry and Commerce when in opposition that they would start with the news agency?
It indicates the determination of this Government to make use of every agency at its disposal to forward the interests of the Irish people and the Irish nation.
Another bit of the programme dropped.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Acquisition of Mayo Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he will state whether the Knox holding (Evans estate) situate at Belgarriff, Foxford, County Mayo, has been acquired by the Land Commission; and, if so, when it is proposed to have those lands divided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands (Mr. Derrig) Thomas Derrig
Speaker.P: The proceedings for the acquisition of the Knox estate at Belgarrow have not yet reached the stage at which it would be possible to indicate the date on which the lands are likely to become available for allotment.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Kildare Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware that an application under Section 14 of the Land Act, 1931, was lodged by Mr. Edward Foley in respect of the lands of Knockfield, County Kildare, on the estate of Mr. John Alfred Cope Corrigan, on the 22nd September, 1950; and, if so, if he will state when it will be possible to deal with this application.
Mr. Foley's application under Section 14 of the Land Act, 1931, is under investigation and a decision will be taken in due course.
Could the Minister give any indication of what “in due course” means?
The application involved two acres approximately, and the inspector has been requested to report and a report from him is expected within a week.
Again a very useful question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Applicants and Land Division.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware of the bitter feelings which exist in the Midlands at the action of the Land Commission in refusing land to suitable landless men and cottage holders and if, in order to remedy this injustice, it is his intention to introduce proposals for legislation to amend the Land Acts so as to provide that local applicants will get their just share of any estates which are acquired for division.

Dissatisfaction, genuine and otherwise, is inevitable whenever an estate is allotted, for the simple reason that the number of applicants in every case exceeds by far the number of holdings that are available. That position is general throughout the country and is not confined to the Midlands.

Landless men and cottage holders are not debarred from receiving allotments. In fact, applications from such persons are always fully and carefully considered and if their applications prove unsuccessful it simply means that there is no land available after more deserving claims have been met.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Land Allotment in Meath.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he will state the total number of migrants allotted holdings in Meath since the first migrant colony was established at Rathcarna, Athboy, County Meath, under the present Government's previous administration.

I presume this question relates to colony and group migration. Colony migration was first undertaken in 1935, and up to 31st March, 1948, 270 colony and group migrants were allotted holdings in County Meath.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Straw for Thatching.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Flynn Mr. J. Flynn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands whether he is aware that officers of his Department prevented the people of Glenbeigh parish from cutting on Rossbeigh Island white straw which was used for thatch on dwelling-houses in the area, and that this action by the Land Commission is imposing serious loss on these people; and, if so, whether he will have the matter re-examined at an early date, and have permission accorded to these people to cut this straw, which constitutes the main portion of their roofing material.

This question appears to refer to the prohibition on the cutting of bent grass at Rossbehy peninsula. Owing to serious deterioration of the bent grass and resultant danger of sand blowing, it was found necessary to prohibit last November the cutting of bent grass or white straw in this area. It would not be advisable, nor in the interests of the tenants themselves to withdraw the prohibition order until all danger of sand blowing is past.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Flynn Mr. J. Flynn
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that the deterioration referred to occurs on one small area of the island only and as the island is three miles in extent will he not advise the Land Commission to allow the people concerned to remove this straw from the other portions of the island? If they are not allowed, it will be detrimental to their interests because they have been using the straw for the past 50 years without hindrance.

It is true that the peninsula comprises a fairly substantial acreage and that the bent grass was planted by the landlord and the tenants had the right to cut the grass for roofing. In 1949, however, it was found that unless the cutting was prohibited the sand blowing would be increased. Expert advice has been given to me that there is a danger owing to the sand blowing of the entire area being destroyed and I think we should persuade the tenants to give up for the present the rights which they had. I will, however, go into the matter further and, if the Deputy wishes to bring any further information before me which would enable me to bring to the notice of the Land Commission that the tenants could be given the right to cut a limited portion of the bent grass without general deterioration, I will go into the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Alien Residents.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether he will state the number of aliens who have taken up residence in Ireland from 1939 to 1950, inclusive, and if he will indicate whether these have been included in the recent census of population which has been published.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Boland) Gerald Boland
Speaker.P: There are, at the present time, 1,934 aliens registered as having taken up residence from 1939 to 1950, inclusive.
All persons resident in Ireland on the night of 8th-9th April, 1951, were enumerated at the census of population.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Salary Arrears.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will indicate when it is proposed to pay arrears of salary to members of the Garda Síochána and the date from which such payments will be commenced.

Payment of arrears of salary to members of the Garda Síochána cannot commence until a revised pay Order embodying the new rates of pay is made. The arrears will be payable from the 15th January, 1951, inclusive. The work of preparing the new pay Order is being expedited as much as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that many of these men are going on holidays in the near future, would it be possible to make some arrangement whereby they could get a “sub” in advance to aid them?

There is this difference between the wages of civil servants and Guards, that there must be a pay Order. That is a rather involved business. I can assure the Deputy that every effort is being made to get payments made as quickly as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: I am not anxious to take the Minister at a disadvantage. I was wondering if there was some way whereby a “sub” would be made available to these people in lieu of money coming to them so that they would have it for the holiday period.
I am afraid there is not.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Promotions in Gárda.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware that a number of sergeants have been on the waiting list for promotion to the rank of inspector for years, and that they are not getting an opportunity of promotion through failure of the Government to fill the vacancies in the rank of superintendent; further if he is aware that this stoppage of promotion is having a bad effect on the Gardaí generally; and, if so, if he will arrange to complete the establishment of superintendents and to make the promotions to the rank of inspector and sergeant resulting therefrom as early as possible.

Three inspectors were appointed to the rank of superintendent on the 20th June, and arrangements are being made to fill the consequential promotions in the lower ranks. There are still four vacancies in the approved strength of the superintendent rank; but one of these posts became redundant on the transfer of Gárda headquarters from Kilmainham to the Depot, and two other posts will not require to be filled until recruiting is reopened.
The fourth vacancy was caused by the recent retirement of a superintendent who acted as ballistics expert to the force. The question of filling this vacancy is being considered.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Probate Registry Delays.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will endeavour to have delays in the principal probate registry eliminated as such delays are causing considerable annoyance and inconvenience to the general public.

I understand that in recent years there has been some delay in the issue of grants of probate or administration by the principal probate registry. These delays have been due to an increase in the volume of the work over the last few years, and the position was aggravated this year by an accumulation of arrears during the period of the bank strike.
I am informed that the peak point has now been passed, and that an improvement in the position may be expected from now on.
Would the Minister take some steps to ensure that there is a survey of the staffing arrangement in the probate registry and other registries in the Four Courts? They are under-staffed.
I understand there has been an improvement in that respect lately.
The Minister should consult his records and he will find that that is not so.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Introduction of Arbitration Bill.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will state whether he proposes to introduce an Arbitration Bill in accordance with the decision of the previous Government.

A provisional draft of an Arbitration Bill which was prepared at the instance of the former Attorney-General by the director of the newly-established statute law reform and consolidation branch of the Attorney-General's Office is at present under examination. So far as I am aware the draft was never before the previous Government nor has it been considered by the present Government and I cannot anticipate the Government's decision.
Can the Minister give any indication as to when he will be able to bring it before the Government?
I cannot. It is under examination.
Will the Minister try to expedite it?
I always try to get things done as quickly as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Strength of Regular Army.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence (1) if it his intention to increase the strength of the Regular Army; (2) if so, to what figure he proposes to increase it, and (3) if he will outline the method by which he proposes to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Traynor) Oscar Traynor
Speaker.P: The reply to (1) is “Yes”.
As to (2), the aim is to bring the strength of the Regular Army up to that provided in peace establishments.

The methods by which it is hoped to increase the strength are at present being given consideration and I feel sure that I can rely on the help of the Deputies of the House and others who may be in a position to assist in whatever efforts we undertake.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: I did not hear the second part of the Minister's reply. Can he not state if he has any definite figure in mind as to what the strength of the Army should be?
Does the Deputy want me to give the strength at which we are aiming?

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: Yes.
Peace establishments. The Deputy will see those in the Estimate.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: Could the Minister not give the figure?
When considering the plans for increasing the strength of the Army, will the Minister consider increasing the pay of the ordinary privates in the Army?
That is a separate question.
Would the Minister give an undertaking to absorb Deputy Cowan's army?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Army Regulations and Political Discussions.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he will quote the Army or military camp regulations which affect (a) the introduction of political discussions amongst Army personnel or in camp quarters; (b) the right of Army personnel to be members of political Parties or to take part in the work of such Parties at elections or otherwise and (c) the right of persons entering on camp quarters in fulfilment of a contract or otherwise to engage in political canvassing, discussions or organisation.
(a) There is no Army regulation or instruction, and it has not been found necessary to issue any, dealing with the introduction of political discussions amongst Army personnel or in camp quarters.
(b) Section 13 (1), Defence Forces Act, however, reads as follows:—
“No officer or soldier of the forces shall join or be a member of or subscribe to any political society or organisation.”
(c) the question of political canvassing in barracks is covered by an instruction of long standing issued by the Adjutant-General of which the following extract is relevant:—
“Canvassers, organisers or agents of political Parties or other interests will not be permitted to enter military barracks or married quarters for the purpose of soliciting votes.
Passes to enter barracks will not be issued to representatives or agents of any Party or interest whatever.”

Can the Minister say whether a person going into a barracks in pursuance of his duty to fulfil a civil contract of delivering goods is entitled to use that opportunity to canvass for political Parties?
No, not according to these regulations which I read out.
Could the Minister say whether a soldier is entitled to canvass outside his hours of official duty?
No, I should say not, but I want to remind the Deputy that these complaints are not one-sided.
I fully appreciate that.

They are very varied and if the Deputy has any evidence which he can produce, I will be very glad to inquire into it. As I have mentioned, I have got several complaints of a similar character, perhaps opposite to the view expressed by the Deputy, but I have received no evidence on which I could have an inquiry conducted.
The Deputy will furnish the evidence to the Minister.
Produce the evidence and I will inquire into it.
I take it the Minister's reply refers only to full-time personnel and not personnel on the Reserve or F.C.A.
Personnel on the Reserve have nothing to do with this at all.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Collins Mr. S. Collins
Speaker.P: Does the Minister not think that the State has grown up sufficiently now to abandon this type of regulations altogether and that if a man wants to have a political opinion, he should be let have it?
That is another day's work.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Army Postal Voters.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence why ballot papers for postal voting were not sent by his record section at the recent election to four members of the Defence Forces stationed at Curragh Camp.

When completing Form E.A.5, that is, Statement of Member of the Defence Forces of Ireland under Section 1 (7) of the Electoral Act, 1923, certain members of the Defence Forces opted to vote in person in the Constituency of Kildare. Accordingly, their names are not on the Postal Voters' List and ballot papers were not received from the returning officer for issue to them.
The members to whom the Deputy refers may possibly be included in that group.
Is it not possible to ascertain with certainty?
If the Deputy can give me the names of the individuals, it would be easy.
The names of the individuals concerned were furnished to the office. I understand it is not usual to put them on the Order Paper.
The Deputy knows that they are excluded from the Order Paper.
I understood that the names would be furnished to the Minister's Department.
Yes.
And they have been furnished to the Minister's Department?
Yes, but they have been excluded from the printed question.
Will the Minister advise me by letter?
I will advise the Deputy by any means that are available.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cork Harbour Forts.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence whether a decision has yet been arrived at regarding the changing of the names of Forts Camden, Temple-breedy, Westmoreland and Carlisle, in the Cork Harbour area to names in keeping with national ideals.
I am considering the matter with a view to renaming the forts in the Cork Harbour area.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Vocational Teachers' Salaries.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether he will indicate if he is prepared to offer, by way of an increase to the vocational teachers, the award made recently by the Civil Service Arbitration Board, in view of the promise made by the previous Minister at the annual congress of the Vocational Education Officers' Organisation held on 11th May, 1951, that this would be done.

asked the Minister for Education if, in view of the general dissatisfaction amongst vocational teachers due to delay in meeting their claim for an increase in salaries, he will, pending a decision in this matter, implement the promise of the previous Government that the Civil Service Arbitration Board's award would apply to vocational teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Moylan) Seán Moylan

MainHeading.P: D'fhiafraí

Speaker.hpid: Peadar Ó Duignéain Peadar Ó Duignéain
Speaker.P: den Aire Oideachais an bhfuil sé ar intinn aige saoire speisialta a thabhairt i mbliana do dhaltaí na Scol Náisiúnta leis an bhfómhar a shábháil.

Speaker.hpid: Seán Ó Maoláin Seán Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: Ní léir dom go mba chóir furmhór mór na scoileanna do dhúnadh mar sin ar feadh coicíse i mí Meán Fómhair nó i mí Deireadh Fómhair muna mbeadh géar-ghá faoi'n am sin leis. Ní bhíonn na daltaí ach tar éis teacht ar ais chun scoile i ndiaidh saoire fada an tsamhraidh, agus ar aon nós, is iad na daltaí sinnsearacha amháin—iad siúd atá ós cionn aon bhliain déag, abair—a bheadh ábalta ar aon chabhair cheart do thabhairt ar an bhfeirm. In a dhiaidh sin is uile, áfach, má thárluigheann droch-shíon ar feadh i bhfad sa bhFómhar i mbliana do b'fhéidir an cheist do bhreithniú as an nua d'fhonn socrú a dhéanamh chun light do na daltaí sinnsearacha fanúint ón scoil ar feadh scathaimh chun cabhair a thabhairt ag sabháil an fhómhair ar fheirmeacha a dtuistí féin.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Buildings.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will state the present position regarding the proposed new school buildings at Ballincollig and Kilmurry, Lissarda, County Cork.

I understand from the Commissioners of Public Works that bills of quantities for the proposed new schools to replace the present Ballin-colling Boys' and Girls' National Schools, County Cork, are being prepared and that it is expected that they will be completed within the next few weeks. As soon as the bills of quantities have been completed, the commissioners will advertise for tenders for the erection of the new schools.

Documentary evidence of title to the site for the proposed new school at Kilmurry, County Cork, has been furnished, and the Department awaits a report from the Chief State Solicitor as to whether the title is satisfactory for the purpose of enabling the site to be vested in trustees, by official lease. The necessary arrangements for the extension of the public water supply to the site have not, however, yet been made. The Department is endeavouring to have the matter settled as soon as possible. When this has been done, and provided that the evidence of title is regarded by the Chief State Solicitor as satisfactory, the Department will sanction a grant towards the cost of the new school.
asked the Minister for Education if he will state when work will commence on the building of Clonrye National School.

As a result of investigations which have been made, it has now been found that it will be feasible to provide water closets, with a septic tank system of sanitation, for the proposed new school at Clonrye. Certain arrangements as regards the production of evidence of title to an additional plot of ground which is required in order to enable water-flushed sanitation to be installed and also as regards the preparation of working drawings and specification for the new school have, however, still to be made before the Commissioners of Public Works will be in a position to advertise for tenders for the erection of the school.

While I am unable to say, at present, when building operations will be commenced, the Deputy may rest assured that all practical steps will be taken to have the remaining necessary preliminary arrangements completed as expeditiously as possible.

Does the Minister seriously put it to me that these stupid preliminaries have not yet been completed in connection with the building of this school? Is he further aware that, due to the state of this shambles, I shall seriously have to consider approaching the county medical officer of health with a view to its being closed down during the coming winter?
I presume that before the operation takes place, there must be a diagnosis.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Convent Extension.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he has approved of the plans for the extra room to be built at the Presentation Convent, Mitchelstown.

Revised sketch plans for a scheme for the extension and improvement of Mitchelstown Convent National School, which were prepared by the manager's architect, are at present under consideration by the Commissioners of Public Works. The commissioners expect to be in a position to furnish a report on the plans at a very early date, and as soon as the report comes to hand the Department will communicate with the manager.

Will the Minister say whether there is any chance of the building of this room, which is going to be used for a secondary school, being expedited? At the moment the space there is very limited. It would be well if it could be started now and finished before next October.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Officials' Leave.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state in respect of officers of local authorities the amount of annual leave specified for each rank or grade, the rank or grade of staff who are and who are not on duty on Sundays, Catholic holidays and bank holidays and the rank or grade of staff who are on duty or on call during the whole period of 24 hours.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Smith) Patrick Smith
Speaker.P: The matters referred to in the question are regulated by the local authorities without reference to the Department, and, consequently, I am not in a position to give the information sought by the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Fermoy Housing Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state whether he has yet given his sanction to the contract for the new housing scheme at Fermoy; and, if not, whether he will expedite the decision in view of the shortage of housing accommodation in that town.

I presume that this question relates to a group of 24 houses which the Fermoy Urban District Council propose to provide at Newtown, Fermoy. Tenders for this scheme were received in my Department yesterday. They are being considered and a decision thereon will be conveyed to the housing authority without avoidable delay.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Castlemartyr Housing Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state the cause of the delay in sanctioning the proposed new housing scheme at Castlemartyr, the plans of which have been with his Department since March of this year.

Some delay occurred in approving a tender for the erection of 34 houses at Castlemartyr while the question as to whether it would be preferable to have the work carried out by direct labour was being examined.
The Cork County Council were notified on the 19th ultimo that there was no objection to their proposal to accept the lowest tender for the work.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cottage Dwellers' Annuities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is prepared, if necessary, by the introduction of proposals for legislation, to give the same benefit, by way of reduced purchase annuities, to occupiers of board of health (county council) vested cottages, as extended some months ago to occupiers of unvested cottages who may in the future acquire their cottages under the Labourers Act, 1936.

The implementation of the suggestion in the first part of the Deputy's question would involve legislation. I understand that the administrative decision of the 9th March last affecting the terms of purchase of unvested cottages was based on representations from representative bodies including the County Councils' General Council. No similar representations have been received in support of a statutory revision of the terms attaching to the purchase of vested cottages.

In view of the fact that there must be preferential treatment given to one section, that is, the unvested cottages, as against the vested, will the Minister give an answer to my question and say whether he is prepared to introduce the necessary legislation?

I have told the Deputy that the administrative decision of the 9th March resulted from a recommendation received from a number of influential bodies, including the General Council of County Councils. These bodies made no reference to the matter which the Deputy refers to in this particular question. For my part, apart altogether from the receipt of any such representations, I would prefer to wait and see how the administrative decision of the 9th March works out before considering the other and wider question.
Is it not clear that I am to take it that the Minister is not prepared to do anything in this matter?
It would be fair to take it that the Minister will approach this, as he will approach every other matter that arises, in a reasonable way.

MainHeading.RHead: Water Supply for County Wexford Cottages
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Water Supply for County Wexford Cottages.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that there are 17 cottages at Ballyhack, County Wexford, with no available water supply and that this hardship has persisted over a number of years; and, if so, if he will take steps to have a pump installed forthwith.

asked the Minister for Local Government if he will have a pump installed at the Hook, County Wexford, as the only water supply of any sort available for human beings or animals in the immediate vicinity is an open well that is frequently contaminated by sea water in rough weather.
With your permission, a Chinn Chomhairle, I propose to reply to Questions Nos. 53 and 54 together.
The provision of pumps is a matter for the sanitary authority. I shall have the Deputy's representations in regard to both places conveyed to the Wexford County Council.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Waterford Water Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether he can indicate what the difficulties are that prevent the Lismore, Cappoquin, County Waterford, water scheme from being put up for contract, and if he is aware that the newly completed housing scheme in Lismore cannot be let for tenancy because of the shortage of water in that town; and, if so, if he will state the date it is hoped to start the scheme and when it is likely to be completed.

I would refer the Deputy to the reply given to his question of the 13th March, 1951, in which the position regarding this scheme was explained. Several major matters affecting the design of the scheme have yet to be resolved by the county council and its technical advisers. In an endeavour to bring the matter to a more advanced stage inspectors of the Department have gone to Waterford this week. I am informed that temporary measures have been taken by the county council to augment the existing supply in the town of Lismore, in consequence of which it will not be necessary to defer the letting of the new houses at present being completed there.

Is the Minister aware that the consultative engineer who attended at the council meeting some three weeks ago said that the sole delay lay with the Department of Local Government and that the emergency provision instituted by the council to pump water from the council pump to the council houses has been proved to be an absolute failure? If he was not aware of these matters, will he now take steps to see that sanction is given to the scheme so that the council can be in a position to go ahead and let the cottages at the earliest possible date?

I have no desire either to accept or to reject the claim made by local authorities that delays are the responsibility of the Department of Local Government, because I think that is a rather futile sort of business. I have told the Deputy that inspectors from the Department have gone down there this week and, according to the advice I have received, steps have been taken, pending final solution of the problem, which will enable the cottages, when completed, to be distributed to the people who are deserving of them.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kinsale Grant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government whether he is aware that an application has been received from Kinsale Urban Council for a grant, under the Local Authorities (Works) Act, of £2,000; and, if so, whether he is prepared to make the allocation.

The Kinsale Urban District Council has submitted 12 schemes under the Local Authorities (Works) Act for consideration for grants in the current financial year. The other two schemes are not regarded as suitable for execution under the Act and are not, therefore, being approved.

asked the Minister for Local Government if he will indicate the present position regarding the proposed Timoleague-Courtmacsherry water supply scheme.

Will the Minister say if this matter will be expedited?

I appreciate that but, knowing the delay that there is in general, which is not the fault of the Department——

asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state the present position regarding the proposed Bandon sewerage scheme and if he will indicate the approximate date on which work will be commenced.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kildare Sewerage Scheme.

Revised plans for a sewerage scheme for Kildare received recently from Kildare County Council have been approved, subject to further examination by the council of certain aspects of the scheme.

I have no functions in respect of the vesting of particular bogs in local authorities for turf production. I want to assure the Deputy that the general understanding between the local authorities concerned and my Department is that, while they have an obligation, of course, to go ahead and discharge their responsibilities, those responsibilities should be discharged without inconveniencing any person, or, if they have to be inconvenienced, to the least possible extent. On a point of order. There are two motions before the House and both are being debated. I am speaking now entirely from recollection, but I suggest, with respect, that neither the mover of the first motion nor the mover of the second motion has a right in a matter of this kind to conclude, or to make a second speech.
The mover of a motion in the Dáil has the right to reply.
Very well.
The Taoiseach rose to ask might he say a few words. We are all quite familiar with that formula in this House, and we have never known it to stop that.
No Deputy offered himself. The Taoiseach rose, and I assumed that the Taoiseach rose to reply.

On a point of order. I confidently trust in you, Sir, to reserve my right to speak on the motion proposed by Deputy Fagan and seconded by Deputy Oliver Flanagan, and lest you might be under any misapprehension through my failure, for want of agility, I should like to say that I desire to contribute to the debate, and to be seen as soon as your convenience will permit.
He wants to talk through his hat.
The Chair called on the Taoiseach to conclude the debate.
Nobody heard you say that, Sir.
On a point of order. This is a serious matter. (Interruptions.)

There is no need for the Chair to say definitely, “The Taoiseach to conclude.” The Taoiseach, as the mover of the motion, rose when no other Deputy offered himself to make a contribution to the debate. I definitely rule that the Taoiseach is concluding.

Will the Chair allow me to make a further submission? I submit that the Taoiseach may have the right to conclude on a motion which he has moved himself, but he has not the right to conclude the debate on a motion moved by Deputy Fagan. That is a right which Deputy Fagan holds equally with the Taoiseach or with any other member of the House.
Are the two motions not being discussed together?
On the point of order, I am making the submission that Deputy Fagan, or any other Deputy, is equal before the Standing Orders with the Taoiseach.
The Deputy will understand that a decision on the motion which I am going to put will decide whether there will be any motion at all before the House.

What I am putting to you, Sir, is this that Deputy Éamon de Valera, the Taoiseach, is being allowed to conclude not merely on a motion which he moved himself, but to conclude the debate, and that Deputy Fagan is being deprived of his right to conclude on his motion.
That is entirely incorrect. The Taoiseach is getting no privilege that any other Deputy would not get.
That is what he is claiming.
Well, he is not getting it. The Taoiseach is concluding the debate, and I am putting the motion.

On a point of order. I am an Independent Deputy and I have as much right to be heard in this House as any member of the Government. A motion has been made by Deputy Fagan, an Independent Deputy. It has been seconded by Deputy Oliver Flanagan, an Independent Deputy. Common courtesy demands that, if the Taoiseach rises in this House and seeks to catch the Ceann Comhairle's eye, Deputies will naturally give way. I am claiming my right to intervene in the debate on the motion moved by Deputy Fagan and seconded by Deputy Oliver Flanagan, and I look to you, Sir, to protect that right.

I do not presume to be an authority on common courtesy. I do endeavour to know as much as I can of the Standing Orders, and the Standing Orders provide that when a Deputy moves a motion in the Dáil he has the right to reply. No other Deputy offered himself, and I called on the Taoiseach. It is the loss of other Deputies who wished to speak if they did not rise. If Deputies, through the operation of common courtesy, did not offer themselves to the Chair, instead of the Taoiseach, well that is not the business of the Chair. I am now ruling definitely that the Taoiseach is concluding the debate.

Speaker.P: On a point of order. The present situation is that there are two motions before the House. One is proposed in the name of the Taoiseach and the other in the names of two Independent Deputies. Does your ruling now mean that the Chair of this House is ruling preferentially in favour of one Deputy who has the same standing as any other Deputy on a motion, and ruling that the motion standing in the names of Deputy Fagan and Deputy Oliver Flanagan, neither of whom has been asked to conclude——

The motion in the name of the Taoiseach.

Deputy Fagan to conclude on his own motion.

If Deputy Dillon persists I will have to ask him to leave the House.
